subject: Re: reg. JUnit
msgSnippet: ... Arithmetic ... methods should start with a lowercase, so: addition() ... Why do you do all of this?  Why not just return x+y; Same for the other methods.
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Manjunath B.M" <bmanjunath@i...> wrote:
> Hi Pallavi,
> Here is the sample program to add subtract and multiply two numbers. The
> test case written in Junit is attached below.

I have a few.. somewhat significant quibbles with this.. see below:

> ----------------------------------
> public class AirthmaticOperation {

Arithmetic

> public void AirthmaticOperation(){
> }
>
> public int Addition(int x, int y) {

methods should start with a lowercase, so: addition()

> int z=0;
> z=x+y;
> return z;
> }

Why do you do all of this? Why not just

return x+y;

Same for the other methods.

> The test case for the above program in junit is :
> -------------------------------------------------
> import junit.framework.*;
>
> public class ArithmaticTestCase extends TestCase {
>
> AirthmaticOperation arithmaticoperation=null;

This isn't used.

> public ArithmaticTestCase(String s) {
> super(s);
> }

Only needed with versions of JUnit prior to 3.8

> public static TestSuite suite() {
> TestSuite suite= new TestSuite();
> suite.addTest(new ArithmaticTestCase("testAdd"));
> suite.addTest(new ArithmaticTestCase("testSub"));
> suite.addTest(new ArithmaticTestCase("testMul"));
> return suite;
> }

Let JUnit create the suite. By writing your own suite method, you are
specifying the order in shich the tests will run... the first step on
a very slippery slope.

> public void testAdd() {
> AirthmaticOperation arithmaticoperation = new AirthmaticOperation();
> assertTrue(arithmaticoperation.Addition(3,4) == 7);
> }

You should be using

assertEquals(7, arithmaticoperation.Addition(3, 4));

Only use assertTrue/assertFalse when appropriate. Use a more specific
assertion whenever possible, such as assertEquals, assertNotEquals,
assertNull, etc.

The creation of the AirthmaticOperation instance should be refactored
out to a setUp() method (and that would use the instance variable you
had defined). Also, that instance shoudl be arithmaticOperation (note
the uppercase "O").

Hope this helps make your tests better in the future. You did have
nice small tests rather than stuffing all the assertions into one.
That's a good thing.

Dave
